story:
The TL;DR: 

This IndieGoGo will cover the costs of paying everyone involved, helping us keep the same high standards we had for season one and create season two on a faster timeline. The episodes will be slightly longer than season one and there will be a larger cast for season two, which is why I’m turning to crowdfunding to help make it happen.

If you want to support indie audio drama with diverse creators & casts, this is a great way to do it!

What people are saying about season one: 

  • First Impressions: “Unplaced” a Haunting Audio Drama Discusses Isolation and Erasure
  • “It's skillfully written and acted, and it's got a fantastic soundtrack.” — Radio Drama Revival (On Twitter: “...an audio drama that explores the isolation & dissociation of urban life with a eerie twist.”)
  • “If you're into urban sci-fi with a hint of horror and a lot of mental illness themes, definitely check this audio drama out!” — Lucille Valentine (via Twitter) 
  • “...the music plucked me right out of my body, put me in the dissociating narrator’s life, and set me spinning.” (via Twitter) 

Mockup of "Punch Your Monsters" shirt design ($45+ backer perk) 

About the crew: 

I’m Michelle Nickolaisen, the writer and creator of Unplaced. I had the idea for it after a particularly rough patch of my life, where I started to feel disconnected from everything around me.

I scripted season one in March of 2017, had it beta-read and edited by May 2017, and started releasing in October (launching on Friday the 13th! ? ). I anticipate the turnaround time from finished scripts to launch to be much faster for season two, due to not having to find my main actor or an audio engineer. I’ve also successfully completed and fulfilled a Kickstarter before, so I have experience managing crowdfunding campaigns and projects of this scope.

In addition to me, there’s Cole and Brendan:

  • Cole Burkhardt is the primary voice actor/the mostly-unnamed narrator for season one.
  • Brendan Hutchins is the audio engineer/editor/sound designer and soundtrack composer.

There will be more actors for season two, but we haven’t started auditioning yet.

Cost breakdown: 

Our goal is set for $3,000, which will cover all of the audio production costs (possibly with some money left over — we’re working off a rough estimate right now, as I have outlines and some scripts for season two, but don’t have runtimes yet for the episodes). That still leaves me paying the actors for season two out of pocket, but that's a cost I can cover if I have to. 

If we reach that goal, whatever we raise over the initial goal will go towards paying the actors. After that, funds will go towards increasing the hourly rate for the actors, then for paying for me to take time off work to finish season two faster. 

If we don’t meet the goal, I’ll put whatever money we do receive to paying for production costs, and season two will still happen — it just might be on a slower timetable. 

Stretch goals: 

Of course, we'd love to cover more than the base cost for audio engineering, which is why we have a whole host of stretch goals! 

  • $3,500: We'll release an “audiobook” version of Unplaced season one (all of the episodes cut together in one file without the outros)
  • $4,000: We'll give season two the audiobook treatment as well, and release it to backers once we're done recording/producing S2 
  • $4,500: Everyone backing at $25 and higher will get a physical script book with all of the scripts for seasons one and two 
  • $5,000: We'll do a public, remastered re-release of season one
  • $5,500: We'll record behind-the-scenes commentary audio for each episode of season one
  • $6,000: We'll record behind-the-scenes commentary audio for each episode of season two
  • $6,500: Everyone backing at $25 or higher will get script books for seasons one and two that are also annotated (get all the notes on notes on why I chose specific names or locations, what got changed between drafts, and why) and signed (definitely by me, Michelle, and if we can figure out the logistics, by the whole crew) 

Campaign/production timeline: 

  • Wrapping up scripts while the campaign runs (May 14th —  June 28th)
  • Aiming to have scripts drafted and sent to beta readers in June
  • Start production late June (possibly sooner depending on editing time/beta feedback) 
  • First episode drops in mid to late July

story:
Hello friends! 

First of all, thank you so much for being some of the cutest people I've ever met. 

I've set a pretty mammoth task this year, in order to get Pigletish off the ground so I can give it the time and attention it deserves. I'm inviting you to help me reach two of my main goals, which are: 

1,000 individual donors
Raise £6,000 together

Not only would the money make a real difference in the quality of content I'm able to create, it would also be mean that I could get the word out about Pigletish and help it reach people who may need it. The money would go towards:

  • Making sure I can work on Pigletish full time, without compromising my own mental health by working two jobs. 
  • Marketing - while social shares have been by far the most effective way of reaching new people, I've also learned that sponsored posts really pack a punch when it comes to spreading the word! 

If you are already one of my readers/listeners, first of all THANK YOU! I wouldn't be able to raise awareness without you, and your messages of support and thanks really make all the work totally worthwhile. Secondly, if you each donated £3 today, I'd reach my goal within 24 hours (Wow!). 

Think about it, that's just 1 fancy coffee at Starbucks, or just over a pint, or a sandwich, or half a hat that costs £6 in the sale at Accessorize. It isn't very much money, but it will make a HUGE difference to me and ultimately to my readers, followers and listeners. 

Thank you so much for being a part of this, I couldn't do it without you! 

Anneli

About Pigletish

The site was launched in March 2017 and is dedicated to raising awareness for Anxiety, PTSD and other chronic and mental illnesses. 

Initially, the site was set up as a way for me to document my journey to recovery from Post Traumatic Stress Disorder (and all it's hideous symptoms), following an abusive relationship. Through your encouragement and support, it has grown into 2 blogs and a podcast that has reached over 13,000 people in 69 different countries. 

The site continues to grow because it runs on the simple idea that talking to each other about mental illness and sharing our experiences helps us feel better understood and less isolated. I don't know how many of you that I have helped directly with my work, but I do know that you have all helped me. I can also tell you anecdotally that I have had several messages from my readers/followers that pigletish has helped you build the courage to speak up about your own illnesses and seek help. 

Real Goal

I've talked about my funding goal above, but I think it's really important that you understand my REAL GOAL, which is this: 

To reach as many people as possible with my two main messages

  1. Hey. It's OK to be ill. 
  2. You're not alone.

Messages which I think are being missed among all the sunset shots and bikini pics that is social media. I want to use my platform to make people feel better about themselves, not worse. 

 

Successes

Some of the Articles have been featured in Huffington Post UK, Quiet Club org and mentioned by BBC's Quite Interesting on Social Media. Other organisations who have shared my content and/or plan to work with me in the future include Women's Aid, The Blurt Foundation, Refuge, Mind Charity and Rethink Mental Illness. I was also nominated by a reader for the Janey Antoniou Award in 2017. 

More recently (just last week) I was contacted by Stephen Fry's PA to let me know that he intends to respond personally to the open letter I wrote him in November last year (I'm equal parts thrilled and petrified to read what he has to say!)

The best critical acclaim I've had has come from my readers, you can see some of their messages on the About page of the site. 

Risks and Challenges: 

I've been able to regularly update the website (mostly each week since March 2017), despite having to also work full time in order to financially support my goals. I have also engaged in daily chats about mental health and mental illness with my social media followers, offering advice and information where possible, and signposting them to appropriate charities and organisations where needed. 

I am confident that Pigletish will only improve with more time invested from me, and that I can keep the all important topic of mental illness and mental health at forefront of minds and conversations. 

I'm also committed to using the time I will be able to work on Pigletish to find brands, organisations and companies to work with in order to fund Pigletish long term. Although Pigletish is strictly non-profit and all money raised will go back into the site, I'm determined to make sure that it becomes sustainable and able to fund itself within 6 months. 

I know we can do this!!! 

Thank you SO MUCH for your ongoing support.
story_txt:
Hello friends! First of all, thank you so much for being some of the cutest people I've ever met. I've set a pretty mammoth task this year, in order to get Pigletish off the ground so I can give it the time and attention it deserves. I'm inviting you to help me reach two of my main goals, which are: 1,000 individual donorsRaise £6,000 togetherNot only would the money make a real difference in the quality of content I'm able to create, it would also be mean that I could get the word out about Pigletish and help it reach people who may need it. The money would go towards:
Making sure I can work on Pigletish full time, without compromising my own mental health by working two jobs. 
Marketing - while social shares have been by far the most effective way of reaching new people, I've also learned that sponsored posts really pack a punch when it comes to spreading the word! 
If you are already one of my readers/listeners, first of all THANK YOU! I wouldn't be able to raise awareness without you, and your messages of support and thanks really make all the work totally worthwhile. Secondly, if you each donated £3 today, I'd reach my goal within 24 hours (Wow!). Think about it, that's just 1 fancy coffee at Starbucks, or just over a pint, or a sandwich, or half a hat that costs £6 in the sale at Accessorize. It isn't very much money, but it will make a HUGE difference to me and ultimately to my readers, followers and listeners. Thank you so much for being a part of this, I couldn't do it without you! AnneliAbout PigletishThe site was launched in March 2017 and is dedicated to raising awareness for Anxiety, PTSD and other chronic and mental illnesses. Initially, the site was set up as a way for me to document my journey to recovery from Post Traumatic Stress Disorder (and all it's hideous symptoms), following an abusive relationship. Through your encouragement and support, it has grown into 2 blogs and a podcast that has reached over 13,000 people in 69 different countries. The site continues to grow because it runs on the simple idea that talking to each other about mental illness and sharing our experiences helps us feel better understood and less isolated. I don't know how many of you that I have helped directly with my work, but I do know that you have all helped me. I can also tell you anecdotally that I have had several messages from my readers/followers that pigletish has helped you build the courage to speak up about your own illnesses and seek help. Real GoalI've talked about my funding goal above, but I think it's really important that you understand my REAL GOAL, which is this: To reach as many people as possible with my two main messages
Hey. It's OK to be ill. 
You're not alone.
Messages which I think are being missed among all the sunset shots and bikini pics that is social media. I want to use my platform to make people feel better about themselves, not worse.  SuccessesSome of the Articles have been featured in Huffington Post UK, Quiet Club org and mentioned by BBC's Quite Interesting on Social Media. Other organisations who have shared my content and/or plan to work with me in the future include Women's Aid, The Blurt Foundation, Refuge, Mind Charity and Rethink Mental Illness. I was also nominated by a reader for the Janey Antoniou Award in 2017. More recently (just last week) I was contacted by Stephen Fry's PA to let me know that he intends to respond personally to the open letter I wrote him in November last year (I'm equal parts thrilled and petrified to read what he has to say!)The best critical acclaim I've had has come from my readers, you can see some of their messages on the About page of the site. Risks and Challenges: I've been able to regularly update the website (mostly each week since March 2017), despite having to also work full time in order to financially support my goals. I have also engaged in daily chats about mental health and mental illness with my social media followers, offering advice and information where possible, and signposting them to appropriate charities and organisations where needed. I am confident that Pigletish will only improve with more time invested from me, and that I can keep the all important topic of mental illness and mental health at forefront of minds and conversations. I'm also committed to using the time I will be able to work on Pigletish to find brands, organisations and companies to work with in order to fund Pigletish long term. Although Pigletish is strictly non-profit and all money raised will go back into the site, I'm determined to make sure that it becomes sustainable and able to fund itself within 6 months. I know we can do this!!! Thank you SO MUCH for your ongoing support.

story:
Short Summary

Hi my name is Jasmine and I want to first say thank you for reading about my project. I am creating this campaign to raise money for a podcast that I am creating. The podcast is titled "The Youngest in Charge" , it is a seasonal show that centers around black millennial entrepreneurs in different industries. The show will have a podcast interview component, as well as a visual component for both Instagram and YouTube. I chose to do millennial entrepreneurs because that generation is considered the gamechangers when it comes to business, and I want to explore that looks like from their perspective.

What We Need & What You Get

So, there is a cost associated with the show. The show will cost $5,000 to create a quality show.  The $5,000 will be spent as follows:

-$2,000 for camera equipment rental for 1 week

-$1,000 for a camera crew for 1 week

-$500 for photography studio for 1 week

-$500 for food for crew for 1 week

-$500 for marketing

-$500 for donation perks

For everyone that donates over $50 they will receive a "thank you" t-shirt.

The Impact

So why should you donate? Great question!

My goal is to create content that is reflective of my community and that discuss topics that are important to the community and culture. Your contribution will do just that. Your contribution also allows me to create more content and give opportunities to others who have stories to tell. 

Risks & Challenges

The risks and challenges that I am likely to experience is not reaching my funding goal. If I am unable to reach the goal, the project will stall until it is fully funded.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute no problem, I just ask that you share it on your social media platforms.

story:
Attention Brimstone Valley Mall Shoppers!

Brimstone Valley Mall is a fast-paced fiction comedy podcast about four demons from Hell who work in a shopping mall in the 90s. This 9-episode first season will be chock full of quippy dialogue, 90s references, dark humor, and of course, a goth garage band (whose lead singer goes mysteriously missing). To sum it up, Brimstone Valley Mall is a nostalgic love letter to suburban mediocrity and trashy mall culture - and that love letter comes dressed in black from head to toe (from Hot Topic, of course).

 

Who is responsible for this horrible horrible thing??

BVM is a product of the Whisperforge, a podcast collective known for hit indie fiction podcasts such as: 

  • Ars Paradoxica 
  • The Far Meridian 
  • StarTripper!!
  • Caravan

The show is written and created by Kristen DiMercurio, with script editing & consulting by Talia Rochmann and Mark Wolf Roberts.

 

Our Budget Breakdown

Does $8000 sound expensive for an indie podcast? You're right! It is.

We may be cretins from the underworld, but even we want to pay our cast/crew a fair wage for their talent, time, and hard work. That means paying NYC prices for our recording space, our actors, and designers.

We also believe that you as supporters deserve full transparency about where your money goes. So, here is our full budget breakdown: 

  • Actors:
    • Main Cast: $50 x Episode = $1675
    • Featured Supporting Cast: $50 x Episode = $600
    • Walk on/Cameo Roles: $10 x Episode = $350
  • Recording Space: 
    • ​28 hours of recording time in a NYC recording studio = $1680
  • Sound Designers:
    • Paying our team of two sound designers for a 9 episode season = $2670
  • Production Costs: 
    • ​Show art = $400
    • Custom Music = $100
    • Indiegogo Fees = $400

Gifts4Goths

What perks do you get out of this? Well, that depends on how goth you are.

  • Goth ($5) - At this tier you'll be listed as a supporter on our website! 
  • Really Really Goth ($25) - At this tier you'll receive the previous reward, as well as a custom ms paint demon makeover that will get shouted out on our social media channels! You'll also receive a BVM button and sticker package!
  • Head to Toe Goth ($50) - At this tier you'll receive all previous rewards, along with exclusive access to a short blooper reel from inside our recording sessions! Your name will also be read out in thanks at the end of an episode of Season 1 of Brimstone Valley Mall!
  • Goth to the Core ($100) -  **THE FIRST TEN DONORS AT THIS TIER GET A LIMITED EDITION BVM TOTEBAG!** At this tier you'll receive all previous rewards, and access to  extended blooper reels, both from our recording session and from the writers meetings! You'll also get  a personal thank you note!
  • Hot Topic Employee ($250)  At this tier you'll receive all previous rewards, and Kristen will draw a cartoon portrait of you as a mall demon! Like this one! 
  • Actually From Hell ($500) At this tier you'll receive all previous rewards, along with ad space to promote your own project (subject to approval) on Brimstone Valley Mall! 
  • Lucifer's BFF ($1000) HOLY HELL YOU ARE TOO COOL. At this tier you'll receive all previous rewards, along with an invitation to our cast party in NYC! Meet and hang for an evening with the weirdos who make the show! 

 

Risks & Challenges

As with any comedy, timing is everything. Our cast is funny as Hell, but even these comedy ghouls need to record in the same room to make this quippy back-and-forth dialogue land just right. 

This means the biggest challenge that we foresee is monetary. Herding 7 actors at a time into a professional recording studio in NYC will not come cheap, but we think the upfront costs will be very very worth the lasting quality (both sound-wise, and performance-wise).

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Brimstone Valley Mall is a monstrous glaring beacon of capitalism in an otherwise also completely capitalistic world. However, sometimes, shelling over your hard-earned cash just isn't in the cards.  So if you're low on funds but high on enthusiasm, then here are some other great ways you can support  the show!

  • Follow us on social media:
    • Twitter: @bvmpod
    • Tumblr: @brimstonevalleymall
    • Instagram: @brimstonevalleymall
    • And our website: www.brimstonevalleymall.com
  • Use indiegogo's share tools to spread the word about our fundraising campaign! 
  • Listen to the show (once it's out), those download numbers make a big difference when trying to book ad sponsorships down the line!
  • Want to make recurring monthly donations? Keep an eye out for info on our upcoming patreon page! Patreon will be funding our season This will be blasted all over our socials as soon as it's live, so if you follow us on any platform, you won't miss it!

Listen to the show (once it's out), those download numbers make a big difference when trying to book ad sponsorships down the line!

story:
Mon projet

Je suis Boris Proulx, journaliste québécois. J'ai réalisé au courant de l'été 2018 ma première série de baladodiffusion, appelée Catalogne en suspens.

Suite à ce travail, l'ex-président de la Catalogne, Carles Puigdemont, en exil en Belgique, accepte de m'accorder une interview en français le 7 novembre prochain. Je veux filmer la rencontre et en faire un document accessible à tous sur YouTube. J'ai trouvé une équipe technique déjà sur place en Belgique à faible coût.

Je suis totalement excité à me rendre en Europe afin de réaliser cette entrevue unique mais un tel voyage nécessite votre aide financière. En contrepartie, je vous propose de poser votre propre question à Carles Puigdemont. 

Le temps me presse, et chaque dollar compte ! 

Objectif : 1000$

La campagne se termine le 7 novembre 2018

Vous pouvez écouter les premiers chapitres de Catalogne en suspens sur votre application de podcast préférée, ou ici :

https://itunes.apple.com/ca/podcast/catalogne-e...

 

Merci d'avance à tous et à toutes!

Boris

story:
Short Summary

Shadow Opera is a creative collective specialising in innovative music theatre. We explore new ways of making and sharing opera with the curious. 

Drawing on the true story of Katherine Bradley and Edith Cooper — two female Victorian poets and lovers who lived and wrote under the pseudonym, Michael Field — our opera podcast brings to life the story of these two extraordinary women. 

Combining operatic vignettes, sound design and interviews, with a libretto assembled from Michael’s journals and poetry set to new music by Tom Floyd, we promise listeners a rich and entertaining audio experience, revealing the sensual, fantastical and witty world of Michael Field and his struggle with Victorian patriarchy.

Covid-19 has been a devastating year for theatre-making, but the show must — and can — go on. All  stages of this project can be completed in even the most severe lockdown restrictions, and the lower production costs of an audio-based project mean that at least 80% of the funds raised will go directly to the singers, instrumentalists, sound team and other creatives involved.

Recording begins in January, with episodes released every two weeks from February. Your support will help employ a brilliant team of creatives to bring this powerful story to life, and enable us to share it with a larger audience than we've ever reached before. 

 

What We Need & What You Get

It's a difficult time to be fundraising, but we know you don't want to see our vibrant arts scene wither. We're spreading our fundraising campaign across 3 income streams:

  • An Arts Council England national grant bid
  • Private sponsorship
  • This Crowdfunding campaign 

We are looking to secure the majority of our funds through grants and sponsorship, however, the support given to our crowdfunding page will be crucial to us in achieving this. It's not what you give that's important: just giving something helps us show there's an audience out there, backing us.

As well as the warm, fuzzy feeling of supporting the arts in these difficult times, we will also be offering supporters perks, including Veritable Michael merch, a special bonus episode and live-streaming events.

 

Impact

This project will help Shadow Opera in its quest to dismantle some of the barriers between opera and mainstream audiences. We think there's huge potential in bringing opera into the world of podcasting and docudramas, both of which have exploded in recent years.

Your support will be help us bring the drama of opera into the more intimate world of podcasting,  exploring a completely new way of making opera, and helping it find new audiences along the way. You will also be helping us provide safe, exciting work for singers, instrumentalists and other creatives during this precarious time for artists. 

 

Risks & Challenges

Like with anything new there are risks to all this. Maybe the world isn't ready for an operatic docudrama podcast series? But if that's the case, it's not a world we want to live in!

Our talented team brings together creatives who have worked for organisations including the Royal Opera House, English National Opera, Scottish Opera, English Touring Opera, Grange Park Opera and more, and we're confident we'll make something audiences find compelling.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

No matter how small, every donation matters, but there are loads of other ways to support this project. We will be working hard to bring this podcast to as wide an audience as possible, and you can help us by:

  • sharing this campaign through your social network
  • sharing (not just "liking") our social media
  • following us on Twitter @ShadowOpera, on Instagram @Shadow_Opera and like us on Facebook @ShadowOperaGroup
  • joining our mailing list to follow the project
  • shouting about the project to anyone who will (or won't!) listen

 

Any support you can give, finanical or otherwise, is greatly appreciated!

Tom, Sophie & James

story:
Who We Are

We are a team of passionate, dedicated audio fiction podcasters and radio drama performers. 

  • Alexander Danner, (Greater Boston, What's the Frequency?) - Director
    (he/him)

  • Jeff Van Dreason, (Greater Boston) - Exhibitor Relations
    (he/him)

  • Amanda McColgan, (Take the Mass Pike) - Social Media Manager
    (she/her)

    Advisory Board

  • Jeremy Holstein (Post Meridian Radio Players) 
    (he/him)

  • Julian Jarboe (Mothers and Others)
    (they/them)

  • Rebecca Mahoney (The Bridge)
    (she/her)

  • Liz Salazar (Post Meridian Radio Players)
    (she/her)

  • Jordan Stillman (The Ordinary Epic)
    (she/her)

  • Alex Yun (Station to Station, Procyon Network)
    (she/her)

  • Tau Zaman (Caravan, ars Paradoxica)
    (they/them)

What We're Doing

Independent podcasting has put the tools of broadcast media into the hands of more people than ever before, tapping into the power of sound and voice as storytelling media; contemporary story podcasts span the full gamut of fiction genres, from fantasy, sci-fi, and horror, to romance, psychological drama, and thriller, to the literary and experimental. This growing form incorporates a variety of powerful artistic elements—writing, voice acting, and sound design and production—to create a unique and immersive story experience.

As part of our mission, PodTales fosters a friendly and creative environment for its attendees and features:

  • Free Admission
    By making admission free to the general public, PodTales seeks to expand the audience for independent audio drama and fiction podcasts, as well as offering a rewarding community event.

  • Local Exhibitors
    With an abundance of local podcasters, PodTales offers podcast listeners the opportunity for personal contact with the creators of their favorite podcasts.

  • Special Guests
    PodTales is proud to spotlight nationally known producers, writers, sound designers, and voice actors from inside and outside the Boston region.

  • Family-Friendly Activities
    PodTales ensures that exhibitors with kid-friendly materials are easily found, and offers workshops geared toward both young listeners and budding podcasters.

  • Hands-on Workshops
    Attendees of all ages and skill levels are encouraged to learn the craft of storytelling through sound from experts and educators.

  • Panel Discussions
    PodTales makes a special effort to engage the diverse interests of the Boston community, exploring how independent fiction podcasting responds to popular media, reflects social concerns, and contributes to mass culture.

What We Need & What You Get

For one thing - this show is free!

We'll level with you - even with the support and foundation of MICE (Massachusetts Independent Comics Expo), even the fact that this is a one-day show, even with the little bit of income we'll receive from exhibitors and sponsorships, this show isn't easy or inexpensive. And have we mentioned that it's free? 

Take a look at our overall budget below of $10,000. We're aiming for $3000 each in terms of revenue from exhibitor table fees and sponsorships from local / national companies. That leaves about $4000 dollars left that we need to raise. 


Here's a breakdown of what we need and how you can help:

  • ​Special Guests: we want our guests to be compensated for their time, effort, and travel. We're hoping to have enough in our budget to pay panelists too. 
  • Exhibitors: While exhibitors aren't paid, we want to make sure they're taken care of and happy during the show. We're borrowing a concept from MICE and will have Happiness Officer volunteers, checking in with exhibitors and making sure they feel safe, taken care of, fed, caffeinated, watered, and generally provided for. 
  • Helping Out Creators in Need: A portion of our budget will be set aside for audio fiction creators who may not have the means to attend or exhibit on their own. Your donation could really make the difference in getting someone out there, spreading the news about their show. 
  • Venue, Advertising, & Operations: Much of this goes without saying. We can't have a show unless we have the space, time, energy, and advertising to set it up, work it, and let people know about it. Plus, we need to pay for legal advice, and even the taxes we receive from the revenue for the show (including this IndieGogo campaign). 

As for what you get for your contribution?

  • Credit! For one thing, you get to feel good about contributing to the only festival dedicated to audio fiction in the United States, and we'll list you on our website, or possibly even the show program. 
  • Fun PodTales Merchandise! Including stickers, pins, t-shirts, and more. Just look at that cute little mouse logo. You know you want one! 
  • Service Awards! We'll create your very own flash fiction prose PodTale for you. Or we'll sound design an audio fiction piece of your very own. How cool is that?
  • Sponsorship!  At this level, you help make the show possible, so you get all the benefits that come with that. Credit, your own exhibition booth, your own advertising - whatever perk we have, you've earned it. 

The Impact

PodTales plans to focus specifically on the work of indie creators who are still building their audiences. Your support can literally help build the profiles of independent fiction podcasters of all sizes, as we provide a safe, friendly space for creators to network and learn from each other, no matter what their experience is. What makes us sure we can do that? 

  • We may have never pulled off an event like this before, but we've all planned and created complicated fiction podcasts, some with sprawling casts.
  • We have the benefit of being connected to our partner, MICE (Massachusetts Independent Comics Expo), which has years of experience and can offer lots of guidance. 
  • We are committed to making this work, making it fun, and making it the best little fiction podcasting show possible. 

Risks & Challenges

We've never done this before, so of course there's a risk. We wouldn't be asking for your help if we didn't need it. Not only that, we want this festival to continue beyond this year, so there's pressure on us to succeed. That being said, we feel confident that we'll be able to deliver on our promises. Why?

  • We have a diverse and talented group of audio fiction creators and enthusiasts who understand what it takes to support this art form and are looking for a wide variety of ways to celebrate it. 
  • We're organized, we're driven, we're passionate, and we've already put a ton into work into this idea. We know we can deliver the type of festival audio fiction deserves. 
  • We have you. If you've read this far, we're confident you'll want to support, if not financially, then perhaps in other ways. 

Other Ways You Can Help

We completely understand that  not everyone can afford to pitch in. But if you still want to help, there's other things you can do. 

  • Spread the word on whatever social media accounts you feel comfortable sharing this. 
  • Word of mouth. Talk us up wherever it seems appropriate. The more people who know about us, the better! 
  • Don't forget that Indiegogo has built in share tools! Feel free to use those to help spread the word!

Thank you for reading, thank you for your time. Happy listening!
story_txt:
Who We Are
We are a team of passionate, dedicated audio fiction podcasters and radio drama performers. 

Alexander Danner, (Greater Boston, What's the Frequency?) - Director(he/him)
Jeff Van Dreason, (Greater Boston) - Exhibitor Relations(he/him)

Amanda McColgan, (Take the Mass Pike) - Social Media Manager(she/her)
Advisory Board

Jeremy Holstein (Post Meridian Radio Players) (he/him)
Julian Jarboe (Mothers and Others)(they/them)
Rebecca Mahoney (The Bridge)(she/her)
Liz Salazar (Post Meridian Radio Players)(she/her)
Jordan Stillman (The Ordinary Epic)(she/her)
Alex Yun (Station to Station, Procyon Network)(she/her)
Tau Zaman (Caravan, ars Paradoxica)(they/them)

What We're Doing
Independent podcasting has put the tools of broadcast media into the hands of more people than ever before, tapping into the power of sound and voice as storytelling media; contemporary story podcasts span the full gamut of fiction genres, from fantasy, sci-fi, and horror, to romance, psychological drama, and thriller, to the literary and experimental. This growing form incorporates a variety of powerful artistic elements—writing, voice acting, and sound design and production—to create a unique and immersive story experience.
As part of our mission, PodTales fosters a friendly and creative environment for its attendees and features:

Free AdmissionBy making admission free to the general public, PodTales seeks to expand the audience for independent audio drama and fiction podcasts, as well as offering a rewarding community event.
Local ExhibitorsWith an abundance of local podcasters, PodTales offers podcast listeners the opportunity for personal contact with the creators of their favorite podcasts.
Special GuestsPodTales is proud to spotlight nationally known producers, writers, sound designers, and voice actors from inside and outside the Boston region.
Family-Friendly ActivitiesPodTales ensures that exhibitors with kid-friendly materials are easily found, and offers workshops geared toward both young listeners and budding podcasters.
Hands-on WorkshopsAttendees of all ages and skill levels are encouraged to learn the craft of storytelling through sound from experts and educators.
Panel DiscussionsPodTales makes a special effort to engage the diverse interests of the Boston community, exploring how independent fiction podcasting responds to popular media, reflects social concerns, and contributes to mass culture.


What We Need & What You Get
For one thing - this show is free!We'll level with you - even with the support and foundation of MICE (Massachusetts Independent Comics Expo), even the fact that this is a one-day show, even with the little bit of income we'll receive from exhibitors and sponsorships, this show isn't easy or inexpensive. And have we mentioned that it's free? Take a look at our overall budget below of $10,000. We're aiming for $3000 each in terms of revenue from exhibitor table fees and sponsorships from local / national companies. That leaves about $4000 dollars left that we need to raise. 
Here's a breakdown of what we need and how you can help:

​Special Guests: we want our guests to be compensated for their time, effort, and travel. We're hoping to have enough in our budget to pay panelists too. 

Exhibitors: While exhibitors aren't paid, we want to make sure they're taken care of and happy during the show. We're borrowing a concept from MICE and will have Happiness Officer volunteers, checking in with exhibitors and making sure they feel safe, taken care of, fed, caffeinated, watered, and generally provided for. 

Helping Out Creators in Need: A portion of our budget will be set aside for audio fiction creators who may not have the means to attend or exhibit on their own. Your donation could really make the difference in getting someone out there, spreading the news about their show. 

Venue, Advertising, & Operations: Much of this goes without saying. We can't have a show unless we have the space, time, energy, and advertising to set it up, work it, and let people know about it. Plus, we need to pay for legal advice, and even the taxes we receive from the revenue for the show (including this IndieGogo campaign). 

As for what you get for your contribution?


Credit! For one thing, you get to feel good about contributing to the only festival dedicated to audio fiction in the United States, and we'll list you on our website, or possibly even the show program. 

Fun PodTales Merchandise! Including stickers, pins, t-shirts, and more. Just look at that cute little mouse logo. You know you want one! 

Service Awards! We'll create your very own flash fiction prose PodTale for you. Or we'll sound design an audio fiction piece of your very own. How cool is that?

Sponsorship!  At this level, you help make the show possible, so you get all the benefits that come with that. Credit, your own exhibition booth, your own advertising - whatever perk we have, you've earned it. 


The Impact
PodTales plans to focus specifically on the work of indie creators who are still building their audiences. Your support can literally help build the profiles of independent fiction podcasters of all sizes, as we provide a safe, friendly space for creators to network and learn from each other, no matter what their experience is. What makes us sure we can do that? 

We may have never pulled off an event like this before, but we've all planned and created complicated fiction podcasts, some with sprawling casts.
We have the benefit of being connected to our partner, MICE (Massachusetts Independent Comics Expo), which has years of experience and can offer lots of guidance. 
We are committed to making this work, making it fun, and making it the best little fiction podcasting show possible. 


Risks & Challenges
We've never done this before, so of course there's a risk. We wouldn't be asking for your help if we didn't need it. Not only that, we want this festival to continue beyond this year, so there's pressure on us to succeed. That being said, we feel confident that we'll be able to deliver on our promises. Why?

We have a diverse and talented group of audio fiction creators and enthusiasts who understand what it takes to support this art form and are looking for a wide variety of ways to celebrate it. 
We're organized, we're driven, we're passionate, and we've already put a ton into work into this idea. We know we can deliver the type of festival audio fiction deserves. 
We have you. If you've read this far, we're confident you'll want to support, if not financially, then perhaps in other ways. 


Other Ways You Can Help
We completely understand that  not everyone can afford to pitch in. But if you still want to help, there's other things you can do. 

Spread the word on whatever social media accounts you feel comfortable sharing this. 
Word of mouth. Talk us up wherever it seems appropriate. The more people who know about us, the better! 
Don't forget that Indiegogo has built in share tools! Feel free to use those to help spread the word!

Thank you for reading, thank you for your time. Happy listening!

story:
The most iconic television show for our queer community is coming back, but this time our viewing experience will be vastly different.

 

We don't know about you, but when we watched the original The L Word, we barely had anyone to talk to about it. Some of us watched it in hiding. Some only watched it years after it had aired. 

This time around, we are watching the show together, celebrating our community, proud of who we are!

Much like our popular Talking Teal series, dedicated to the Australian TV show Wentworth, L is for Lady Parts will be our companion vlog series for The L Word: Generation Q. In our vlog series we will dedicate a vlog every week to the new episode, talk about it, analyze it, and incorporate your emails into our review and discussion of the episode.

The premiere is on us. Then, every week, you will have the option of pooling together your funds to make another vlog happen. 

You can give as much or as little as you'd like. Every time the campaign hits another $150 increment, we will do a vlog on the episode of that week.

New episodes of The L Word air on Sundays. New vlogs will be shot on Fridays and posted on Saturdays, which means the campaign has to hit the $150 goal by Tuesday at noon EST after new The L Word episode aired, in order to give us enough time to prepare and you enough time to email us. Deadline for your emails will be Friday at 8am EST, unless specified otherwise.

PLEASE NOTE: We will not be doing episode 5 due to travel. The Indiegogo campaign page is set up to fund six episodes (2,3,4,6,7,8).

You can give as much or as little as you'd like to contribute to as many episodes as possible!

If you fund all six remaining episodes, we will host the wrap party at the end of the season on us!

story:
Le Transistruck, c'est quoi?

Le concept est assez simple : nous allons transformer un camion cube de 12 pieds en studio mobile pour enregistrer et présenter des émissions de radio devant public. Nous allons donner une deuxième vie à un véhicule de livraison FedEx. 

Le Transistruck sera prêt à animer les rues de Gatineau et à sillonner les routes de l'Outaouais en juin 2018. 

Cet ambitieux projet est une réalisation de l'équipe du festival Transistor : Steven Boivin, Julien Morissette, Marie-Hélène Frenette-Assad, Alexandra Aubry-Richard, Karine Robillard et Olivier Charbonneau. 

On a besoin de vous!

Sur un projet de plus de 30 000$, nous tentons de recueillir 5 000$ auprès du public pour boucler le budget et permettre au camion de prendre la route en juin 2018. 

Les étapes que nous allons réaliser sont les suivantes :

  • Sabler, peinturer et débosseler le camion
  • Faire un trou pour une « fenêtre de service » qui nous permettra d'animer et enregistrer devant public 
  • Aménager le studio avec un plancher de bois, des murs de pin et un nouveau plafond
  • Construire le mobilier du studio : table, régie, cuisinette, banquette et lits 
  • Isoler le studio pour qu'il soit utilisable durant toute l'année 

Consultez la liste des articles que nous offrons en échange d'une contribution.

story:
Short Summary

Hi, I'm Jessica Marshall and I've been drawing story sketches for animated TV shows and movies for almost 10 years.  I've spent a lot of time making likable characters find friendship, purpose, and self-esteem.  They've gone on high adventures and sang passionately about wanting to belong in a confusing world.  And after the 2016 election cycle, I never felt more like one of those characters.   I became a news junkie before the winner was even announced, asking the same questions many were: What is a superdelegate?  What's the difference between a caucus and a primary?  Does my vote even matter?

 

I remember as a kid there were shows like Schoolhouse Rock that broke down how a bill became a law and the Preamble to the Constitution.   Are there shows now that speak about our government's inner workings?  I have yet to find them.  And Schoolhouse Rock, although beloved, seems pretty dated.  It was released 43 years ago.  

I was suddenly on a mission to create an animated series that would teach simple civics lessons like on Schoolhouse Rock, with music, but with narrative storytelling from a kid's point of view.  What if ​Glee boarded the ​Magic School Bus and took a ride to ​The West Wing.  But with the insanity of this political climate, it feels as if time is of the essence.  And being that my resources are limited I've decided to produce the idea as a kids narrative podcast. 

I believe the idea is solid and the message is more vital than ever before.

The podcast will be a six-episode season to launch in February (the beginning of primary season and the 2020 election).  But I need your help.   I am overjoyed to report that many talented people have stepped forward to help me create this show. 

And for their efforts and dedication, they deserve compensation.  I am no Scrooge McDuck and so I need to raise funds to pay for talent and equipment. 

 

What we need & What you get

You see it.  And you're on board to help us start a conversation about civics with the future generation of voters.   But you've got questions.  What would I do with the money you contribute to this campaign?  The money will pay for writers, voiceover talent, musicians, sound editors/technicians,  recording space, web services, perks, and advertising. 

And what do you get in return?  Well first, all your dollars will go into bringing you and your kids a fun podcast to sing along to in the car.  Hopefully, it will start good conversations with them about freedom of speech or why we vote...and keep them entertained all the way to school!

Being that this is a podcast we have unique opportunities to honor your contributions.  Whether it is a shout out at the end of the show, naming a character after you or your child, or giving you the most prominent title of executive producer.  We have also made some campaign buttons and bumper stickers to promote the show and Gloria's run for Student Body President.

If we do not reach our financial goal... the funds will still go to this endeavor.  We will just have to find other ways to raise the remaining dollars.  We will also make cost-effective choices to make the project the best it can be with the resources we receive from you- our constituents. 

 

The Impact

Throughout the process of writing and pitching this idea to various people.  I have heard repeatedly, "If ever there is a time we need a show like this, it is now."  Now, when our democracy seems shakey and we question why the founding fathers made the decisions to write the Constitution as they did, we may wish to reflect.  What are the values that are integral to that document that we find important as Americans? 

More than ever before our kids are pushed to excel at math and science to keep up with the changing global market.  Because of this effort, some subjects have been lost in the classroom.  Justice Sandra Day O'Connor noticed a civics curriculum was one of those subjects.  She started an online initiative named iCivics to engage older kids.  It is a valiant effort that deserves more press.  I believe that kids even younger than this can start to understand some basic principles such as leadership, community, and the power of your voice.  My goal with this podcast is to start those conversations outside of school and hopefully bring them back into the classroom, too. 

Risks & Challenges

I am confident we will create a fantastic podcast that will be well received.  I know this just from the talent that has already stepped forward to join me on this mission.  The obstacle that we have to overcome is awareness.  I'm sure that the more people know about this project, the more they will agree that there is a need for shows like this that teach the value of being an engaged citizen. 

We plan to cast a wide net to attract attention through social media groups within the animation, political and educational communities.  Our podcast will have characters that represent the American experience at large.  We hope that kids from all over the States will see our characters as friends to cheer for and become inspired by their ability to affect change at their elementary school through civic action. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

I understand it may be difficult for everyone to donate.  But please don't let that stop you from telling others about our campaign and our mission with the podcast.  If you can hum a couple of bars about that sad little bill sitting there on Capitol Hill,  then you know the impact a fun song can have on a kid.  Please use the Indiegogo share tools and help us make some earworms for the next generation.

story:
Short Summary

For those of you who don’t know me, I spend my time immersed in all issues relate to accounts payable. Now, before you start rolling your eyes, let me also share that this will be my 20th book, and about three-quarters of those books are about accounts payable issues. It is a lot more complicated than it sounds … unless you don’t mind:

  • Getting ripped off by fraudsters,
  • Paying for inefficient processes,
  • Paying some invoices twice (no, most vendors do NOT return the second payment),
  • Late fees
  • Losing early payment discounts
  • Getting in trouble with the IRS for inaccurate or incomplete reporting
  • Similar problems with the SEC

… and more. The list goes on but I’m guessing you might be beginning to see why this is a more complex topic than it appears at first glance. And these problems existed before being exacerbated by the COVID-19 crisis which cast a spotlight on some weak practices, enables some new frauds and made remote working a reality for many.

Time, at least for me, is a precious commodity. But there are only so many hours in a day. We were supposed to go on a cruise in May and I’m guessing you can figure out what happened there. The silver lining to that lost cruise is I had three weeks with no work planned; no articles to write, no talks to give etc. – and no place to go, either.

While we are pretty serious at AP Now, given the nature of our work, we also do like to have a good laugh occasionally. For a long time, I’ve wanted to find a way to include some cartoons in my books. For, people who work in accounts payable have some pretty funny encounters from time to time. So, with my extra time, an introduction from a friend, and hopefully a little backing from you, a cartoonist was hired.

He’s bringing the ideas I’ve been saving to life. Each chapter of this softcover book (and there are about 25 of them) will start with a cartoon, based on “Life in Accounts Payable.”

What We Need & What You Get

The book will have three distinct components:

  1. The book itself with the latest best practice advice and insights. This will be the largest part of the book, probably 90%
  2. The cartoons
  3. A resource section, where readers can find information about the some of the product offerings to help with the accounts payable function.

While we are pros at producing the first component, the second two (cartoons and resource section) are new to us.

Our primary goal of this campaign is to get the book in the hands of as many professionals at reasonable a price as possible. These are the people who regularly read our newsletter, come to our webinars and participate in our surveys. They are accounts payable managers, directors and supervisors; controllers, accountants, auditors and CFOs. And of course, the service providers. The first three perks below are for you.

But we also want to get the word out. We have devised a three-part strategy to gain eyeballs to our best practice information and to the service providers who offer innovative solutions to the accounts payable community. This will be executed as follows:

  1. A companion listing of the resources shown at the back of the book will be put on the AP Now website. It will stay live through the end of 2020.
  2. A Limited Series of 10 Best Practice Podcasts. These are posted on the AP Now website, YouTube and many other podcasting sites.
  3. A social media campaign to draw attention to best practices (Linkedin, Twitter and Facebook).

The Deliverable: The product is a softcover book, which will be sold after publication for $39.95 + shipping and handling. Our goal is to have all copies of the book ordered at the pre-publication price in the mail no later than August 15th, if not earlier!

Will you help me spread the word by backing this project? The special perks shown below were designed just for you.

The Impact

The book will be published, whether we meet the goal or not. It is almost completely written and well, this is my 20th book – so clearly, I can get this type of project completed in a timely manner. If we don’t meet the goal, the social media program will be scaled back.

Your support means that not only can we get this book published, but we can also publicize it widely. I believe wider publicity not only translates into more sales but equally important (at least to me) is that it will help bring wider recognition for the hard work the accounts payable teams are doing for their companies.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

There are many ways you can help us get the word out (whether you contribute or are just a believer in what we are trying to do). Here are a few:

  • If you listen to a podcast, like it or share it with your community
  • If you see a notice on Linkedin, like it, add a comment or share it with your community, your peers, your boss
  • If you see a tweet on Twitter, Like or Retweet it
  • If you see a notice on Facebook, like comment or share it
  • If you read the book, and you like it, please leave a review on Amazon, Goodreads or any other book review site.

And of course, I love to hear from folks who work in, manage or provide services to the accounts payable community. So, please share your thoughts.

Short Summary
For those of you who don’t know me, I spend my time immersed in all issues relate to accounts payable. Now, before you start rolling your eyes, let me also share that this will be my 20th book, and about three-quarters of those books are about accounts payable issues. It is a lot more complicated than it sounds … unless you don’t mind:

Getting ripped off by fraudsters,
Paying for inefficient processes,
Paying some invoices twice (no, most vendors do NOT return the second payment),
Late fees
Losing early payment discounts
Getting in trouble with the IRS for inaccurate or incomplete reporting
Similar problems with the SEC

… and more. The list goes on but I’m guessing you might be beginning to see why this is a more complex topic than it appears at first glance. And these problems existed before being exacerbated by the COVID-19 crisis which cast a spotlight on some weak practices, enables some new frauds and made remote working a reality for many.
Time, at least for me, is a precious commodity. But there are only so many hours in a day. We were supposed to go on a cruise in May and I’m guessing you can figure out what happened there. The silver lining to that lost cruise is I had three weeks with no work planned; no articles to write, no talks to give etc. – and no place to go, either.
While we are pretty serious at AP Now, given the nature of our work, we also do like to have a good laugh occasionally. For a long time, I’ve wanted to find a way to include some cartoons in my books. For, people who work in accounts payable have some pretty funny encounters from time to time. So, with my extra time, an introduction from a friend, and hopefully a little backing from you, a cartoonist was hired.
He’s bringing the ideas I’ve been saving to life. Each chapter of this softcover book (and there are about 25 of them) will start with a cartoon, based on “Life in Accounts Payable.”

What We Need & What You Get
The book will have three distinct components:

The book itself with the latest best practice advice and insights. This will be the largest part of the book, probably 90%
The cartoons
A resource section, where readers can find information about the some of the product offerings to help with the accounts payable function.

While we are pros at producing the first component, the second two (cartoons and resource section) are new to us.
Our primary goal of this campaign is to get the book in the hands of as many professionals at reasonable a price as possible. These are the people who regularly read our newsletter, come to our webinars and participate in our surveys. They are accounts payable managers, directors and supervisors; controllers, accountants, auditors and CFOs. And of course, the service providers. The first three perks below are for you.
But we also want to get the word out. We have devised a three-part strategy to gain eyeballs to our best practice information and to the service providers who offer innovative solutions to the accounts payable community. This will be executed as follows:

A companion listing of the resources shown at the back of the book will be put on the AP Now website. It will stay live through the end of 2020.
A Limited Series of 10 Best Practice Podcasts. These are posted on the AP Now website, YouTube and many other podcasting sites.
A social media campaign to draw attention to best practices (Linkedin, Twitter and Facebook).

The Deliverable: The product is a softcover book, which will be sold after publication for $39.95 + shipping and handling. Our goal is to have all copies of the book ordered at the pre-publication price in the mail no later than August 15th, if not earlier!
Will you help me spread the word by backing this project? The special perks shown below were designed just for you.

The Impact
The book will be published, whether we meet the goal or not. It is almost completely written and well, this is my 20th book – so clearly, I can get this type of project completed in a timely manner. If we don’t meet the goal, the social media program will be scaled back.
Your support means that not only can we get this book published, but we can also publicize it widely. I believe wider publicity not only translates into more sales but equally important (at least to me) is that it will help bring wider recognition for the hard work the accounts payable teams are doing for their companies.
Other Ways You Can Help
Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:
There are many ways you can help us get the word out (whether you contribute or are just a believer in what we are trying to do). Here are a few:

If you listen to a podcast, like it or share it with your community
If you see a notice on Linkedin, like it, add a comment or share it with your community, your peers, your boss
If you see a tweet on Twitter, Like or Retweet it
If you see a notice on Facebook, like comment or share it
If you read the book, and you like it, please leave a review on Amazon, Goodreads or any other book review site.

And of course, I love to hear from folks who work in, manage or provide services to the accounts payable community. So, please share your thoughts.

story:
What's this all for?

It's been quite a long time since I've gone a week without seeing friends online bemoan a lack of low-stakes fiction podcasts. Something with plenty of humor to offset the hundreds of amazing-yet-stressful shows currently running, let alone real life.

Enter Standard Docking Procedure, a workplace sitcom set on a cantankerous middle-of-nowhere space station. With a diverse cast and some elbow grease I'm ready to produce hell of a podcast. All the fun and worldbuilding of sci-fi without waiting for the penny to drop that the alien race du jour is the writer's commentary on racism, sexism, or both at the same time. Meanwhile, with a predominantly LGBTQA+ main cast, we'll be delivering the finest sitcom scenarios but without all of the unfortunate homophobic/transphobic/fatphobic jokes found in a lot of older traditional television sitcoms. 

Nobody's going to suddenly die, nobody's going to suddenly contract a terminal illness. Everything isn't going to go perfectly fine for the characters, it's a story after all, but rest assured we're all leaves on the wind. We'll gently float from story to story together, and that's that. Love, acceptance, and that dangerous feeling of wealth on payday prevail on Pseudopolis. 

What We Need & What You Get

While a lot of excellent fiction shows are produced with little to no vocal talent, I want to buck the trend and make something that makes everyone involved feel better at the end of the day, not just the listener. 

I have a freelance writing job that offsets my existing costs for editing software and podcast hosting. Producing three existing podcasts means I've got the existing ecosystem to act as director/producer/editor/writer/sound designer. I can "pay" my way by dedicating time I'm not at my real job to the show, but voice actors can't live off "Gavin could be playing Mario Party right now" bucks. Voice actors do a hell of a lot of work for not that much recognition/reward in podcasting, I want to help change that in what ways I can. The pilot episode alone has four main characters and six supporting roles, and they all knocked it out of the park. 

Where the Money's Going

See, I wasn't kidding. The lion's share of the campaign will go towards paying voice actors, with a small percentage set aside for crowdfunding fees and a small provision to upgrade the podcast's website once season one is officially underway. 

And, of course, I have some fun perks one can only get by supporting the show! If you've heard the pilot episode, you might still be wishing for a piece of Carloni's 3D pizza. Well, wish no longer! Pledges from $1 up get a file that'll allow them to print out and assemble one of Carloni's delicious* cubes. Pledge at the $25 level and we'll send you a pre-printed version along with every other physical item offered!

*As tasty as they look, the cube is indeed still just paper. Learn from my mistakes.

Risks & Challenges

The biggest challenge the show faces right now are lack of funding. If the campaign does not meet its goal we will produce whatever amount we can afford and then SDP will go on hiatus until such time as I've saved up enough from my real-world spare income to produce another episode, which would change the release schedule to once every few months.

I've kept The Red Light Library and Tuned In, Dialed Up running consistently with only occasional scheduling hiccups for quite some time. Editing and sound design are my passion. If I can keep voice actors gainfully employed, episodes will flow. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Of course, you can also help SDP without spending any money as well! Spread the word on social media, send the pilot episode to your friends! Word-of-mouth really helps podcasts and crowdfunding campaigns, so clicking one of those handy share buttons up above will unlock the best example of synergy you'll (probably) see today.

story:
Hello...?

Hello. My name is John David Booter. I've never made a podcast. The last few years have been full of ups and downs. I was savagely betrayed by my fiancee Lisa, gained 287 pounds and made an eight episode podcast.

To my surprise and delight, DONE DISAPPEARED, the documentary podcast investigative podcast I created with my bare hands, took off at lightning speed.

By Episode 2, we had won The Award for Best New Podcast and were given a key to the city of Davistown Pennsylvania.  We also tripled our Patreon goal of zero dollars a month and got the incredible news that DONE DISAPPEARED was becoming a TV Show Starring me, John David Booter. And that was just the beginning. 

Hundreds and hundreds of millions of listeners tuned into Season 1. The world was riveted and heartbroken by the disturbing case of Clara Pockets, a Pennsylvania woman who went missing in 1987. There were many twists and turns in the investigation and by the end of our podcast, thanks to you our listeners and to me John David Booter and my podcast Done Disappeared with me John David Booter...  Clara Pockets was found. Also thanks to Davistown Police and everyone involved in the investigation over the last thirty years.

But Clara Pockets wasn't the only one who'd been found by the end of my investigation into her disappearance. There was someone else. Someone who had somehow slowly faded away into nothingness over the course of the last few brutal years. That someone was me, John David Booter. And with my podcast, DONE DISAPPEARED with me John David Booter, I, John David Booter, found myself, John David Booter.

 And now? We still have lingering questions in the case of Clara Pockets. Such as: Why? Where did she go? Who took her? What happened to her? Is she doing okay? What's she been up to? Where is her family? Is there a God? and May we speak with him?

We intend to address these questions in the future. But for the most part, Season 2 will focus on a NEW CASE. Last Season, we covered the case of Clara Pockets and eventually caused her to be discovered. This season, we're doing something a little different. We're tackling a case that took place decades ago, in a time almost nobody knows anything about. A time before cell phones, before drones and just after the bicycle was invented. That's right.

 Season 2 will cover a crime that took place in the 1980's!

We've already learned so much about the 1980's in our research for the upcoming season and cannot wait to appropriate the aesthetic of this magical decade for our true crime podcast.

But to do that? We need your help!!

.... What's this all about?

As I led the charge in the (successful) search for missing mother Clara Pockets I was haunted by the endless questions surrounding her mysterious life and disappearance. But I was also tormented by a question which until now had seemed unanswerable. The same question every truly great documentary filmmaker asks every day:  How am I going to monetize my podcast?

With the white-hot success of Season 1, the answer seemed clear. Every podcast distributor from Confoundry to StereoBlam wanted a piece of the tiny DONE DISAPPEARED cake pie. 

But I realized.. the only way to bring DONE DISAPPEARED back in its truest form...  Would be to keep DONE DISAPPEARED a completely independent endeavor between ME, John David Booter, and YOU our listeners. 

As you're surely aware, the first season of DONE DISAPPEARED was blessed with countless sponsors who were unaware of the podcast and we in no way profited from advertising them. It is our goal to keep our sponsors, advertisements and promo codes the same as long as possible. The same meaning: completely at our discretion. And you can bet a bundle of corn-feed that DONE DISAPPEARED SEASON 2 will feature EVEN MORE ADS from your favorite sponsors! Like Blue Apron, SquareSpace, Madison Reed and of course, Big Box of Shit. 

Which reminds me, this campaign doesn't just benefit me, John David Booter, or my podcast, DONE DISAPPEARED with me John David Booter. This campaign benefits all of us. We're offering wonderful rewards to our donors, from a handwritten note with stickers to a BIG BOX OF SHIT sent directly to your doorstep as well as a BLUE APRON Skype date with me, John David Booter and many more exciting opportunities! Please check out our perks to see which one is right for you!

Also Why?

Not only will your contribution help keep Season 2 real-ad free, it will also ensure that it is able to be created at all.

By the end of Season 1, I suffered a crippling loss that will have a profound effect on my ability to move forward with this project. Namely, my 2010 Macbook Pro. The stress of completing hundreds of exports and the lack of an external drive has taken its toll, and the gentle humming of my laptop has crescendoed into a piercing shriek. Now, when powered on for more than fifteen minutes, my computer is hot to the touch. It has become clear to me that this computer will not be able to handle another season. BUT I KNOW WE CAN.

In addition, we would like to include MORE EPISODES in Season 2, but in order to do that we need to EXPAND OUR TEAM! Right now, the DONE DISAPPEARED team consists of me, John David Booter, and our eleven year old composer Johan Johannes Johannesburg. But what we desperately need for season 2 is a sound mixer. Since my background is NOT in podcasting, it took me days, sometimes weeks, and in one case several months to plunk out an edit of a single ten minute episode of DONE DISAPPEARED on Garageband. By hiring a sound mixer, we will be able to bring you more, better-quality episodes in the upcoming season.

I would also like to build a small recording shack in the backyard of my mother June's house. For this I would need: A microphone, a hammer, nails, a bunch of wood, rope? and of course my mother June's permission. Your contributions will help me achieve this daunting task. 

Okay...

In a nutshell, this is an experiment to see if we can monetize our podcast in any way without compromising the product. If we are unsuccessful, we will continue to make DONE DISAPPEARED Season 2, it just may be a much longer road. 

Any contribution, big or small, is hugely appreciated! If you love DONE DISAPPEARED but simply don't have the money to contribute or couldn't be bothered please know you're still one of the best friends we've ever had and the more you can help make sure that word gets out about Clara Pockets and DONE DISAPPEARED the better.

Thank you for listening and THANK YOU for reading. We hope you will consider supporting this fascinating piece.

story:
We can't commit to booking out a pub without knowing we're definitely going to have people turn up though (we all remember Nottingham...), so once again we're crowdfunding it again this year. If we hit our goal, we book the room, it's as simple as that! Plus, anyone who backs the crowdfunding campaign will be rewarded with an exclusive "I made MGPX19 happen" lanyard to wear on the day. Or leave at home. We won't make you wear them...

Just like every other year, the event will be "Pay What You Want", so you can turn up for free on the day if you want, but remember, if we don't fund the project here on IndieGogo, we can't book the pub, so the event will be cancelled. Also, as a super special bonus, just like in every previous year, every pound spent on tickets will get you an entry in to the world famous MGPX raffle - so the more you pay, the more chance you have of winning! In previous years we've given away a PS4, an Xbox One and thousands of pounds worth of other gaming and pop culture swag. We don't know yet what'll be in this year's raffle, but we're pretty confident it'll be worth winning!

story:
Help Uncle Tony & Enam Expand the East Coast MAGA Movement!

We put a lot of effort into getting the truth out there and entertaining you guys while we do it.  Now we need your help taking things to the next level!

$1,850 will launch our new podcast... $5,000 will really expand the platform to include new personalities, travel to more big MAGA rallies, and "Red Pill" blogs.  If we reach the podcast goal, this site will remain open for donations to fund more new expansion.

Uncle Tony & Greg will always be ranting, but some want to hear Tony break things down in detail.  They want to hear Greg tell more tales from Old School Astoria.  Enam has been covering political events in NYC and has met a lot of patriots, free thinkers, and passionate defenders of our constitution who want to collaborate.  We can make all this happen with a new podcast!

Be part of something big- we MAGA together!  100% of your donation will be spent improving the quality of the broadcasts/travel.  Your contribution will launch:

  • Live podcast, twice(+) per week, 60mins+, w/ special guest visits & call-ins.
  • Quality A/V equipment, broadcast software, & proper setting for the podcast.
  • Longer, more frequent, journalistic coverage of political events; better A/V.
  • Better quality video & lighting during Tony & Greg's rants!

*****  This campaign will remain open after we hit the "Podcast" goal.  We'd like to raise $5,000 which would fund further expansion-- travel to more MAGA events for live coverage, bringing on more personalities (more videos) and blog articles!  *****

Please include your email with your donation so we can contact you to fulfill Perks.

What We Need

  Here's the quick rundown:

  • Two microphones appropriate for a quality podcast  
  • Two HD webcams appropriate for a quality podcast  
  • Portable lighting (podcast/rants/journalism) 
  • "Studio" setup costs  
  • Dual phone holder/stabilizer  (journalism & rants)  
  • Camera & gear appropriate for HD video journalism in all weather  
  • 20k mAh battery pack (rants & journalism)  
  • Broadcast Software License
  • Travel costs (events in DC, Boston, etc)

The Impact

Right now, there are millions of people brainwashed by getting all their news in the form of MSM propaganda.  We're getting the truth out there and, if you're at this page, you appreciate truth in media.  Help us expand so we can get the word out to even more people, and make the quality of the broadcasts even better for you.

The more people we reach, the faster they're waking up.  We all remember when we took the Red Pill...

Other Ways You Can Help

 Maybe you can't contribute a donation, that's fine-- you can still help!  Here's how:

  • Share this link on social media.  Tag friends who would appreciate the MAGA Movement.
  • "Like" or upvote the social media post where you found this link-- more people will have a chance to see it.
  • Send this link and the Uncle Tony FB/Twitter link to likeminded friends.
  • Post the link to the comments section of relevant articles.  Don't over-post/spam, though.

We appreciate any help you're able to give.  God Bless!
