story:
STRETCH GOALS:

We're super close to our goal, so I thought I should add our Stretch Goals right up top!

If we reach $12,000: We'll invest in a Twitch streaming setup for the studio, so that we can start doing regular live gaming streams, reaching a wider audience and giving our current audience something fun to look forward to that's interactive and video-based! Regular JackBox streams? Exciting streams of new console games as they come out? Nostalgic romps into old classics? Yes please!

If we reach $15,000: We'll be able to send 2 people from our team to PodCon in Seattle this January, who otherwise wouldn't be able to afford to go! PodCon was really fantastic last year, and it's a great opportunity for networking and meeting fans. We'd love to be able to send a few people to PodCon this year, but we're on the East Coast, so we can't do that without breaking the bank, unless you help us reach this goal!

If we reach $20,000: We'll be able to send 5 people to PodCon, and also have some room in our budget for marketing this year! That would be amazing! Please help make this happen!

Who Are We?

The Upford Network is a new & quickly-growing network of Podcasters & Creators based primarily out of Montreal, Quebec. Our Executive Producer, Tom Zalatnai, and our Director of Programming, Julian McKenzie, launched the network earlier this year, with the goal of providing resources to creators to make high-quality, community-building shows.

We've always recorded out of our studio in Tom's house, where the sound quality is great, but the sound-proofing is not. The reality is, it costs a lot to properly soundproof a room, and since we're in a rental right now, we can't do the type of renovations we'd need to make the space a proper studio.

We're also excited to announce that Tom and his partner, our Chief Copywriter Teffer, are having a baby this Fall! Babies are exciting, but also noisy! So we've collaborated with a crack team of contractors who are going to help us out by building a soundproof recording booth big enough to fit five or six people comfortably, so that all the shows that record at our studio can continue to crank out high-quality programming week after week, without worrying about getting in the way of our little family (and vice versa!)

So, if you love babies and/or podcasts, and want to help us let both those things exist in the same space, consider donating to this campaign!

What's in it for YOU?

The contractor quoted us $10,000 for the job. This includes materials and labor. So that's our goal! We raise $10,000 and you can rest assured that the shows you love will not just continue to exist, but will thrive with an even greater level of audio quality than before!

We've also got a TON of really fantastic perks available! Since our network is made up of so many talented creators with all different skills and talents, we've got a wide array of rewards up for grabs! With low-cost perks like social media shoutouts and exclusive bonus content, and higher-cost ones like having us name our studio (or even our BABY) after you, there's also a bunch of sweet stuff up for grabs in the middle, like signed artwork, handmade stuffed animals, and even advertising opportunities (for those of you with your own projects to promote!)

You can check out the full list of perks on the side of this campaign page to find the one that's right for you :)

Who cares about some podcast network in Montreal?

Hey now, no need to get hostile! You'd actually be surprised at the number of people who've written in over the past three years and told us that one of our shows has made a big difference for them! We're a network that cares really deeply about building community between creators and their audiences, and I think that really makes a difference in people's lives. Having a show to come back to, week after week, where the hosts genuinely care about the people who are listening, helps a lot of people who feel lonely or out of place in the world to feel like somebody's there. 

Risks & Challenges

This is a really scary campaign for us. We have no idea how many of you will even read this far down the page (Hi! Thanks for reading this far down the page!) let alone how many of you will donate! But if we're going to keep making this content we're so passionate about, we really need your help. It's hard to ask people for money. It's such a vulnerable thing to admit that we can't do this alone, especially since there's so many of us. But we can't, because we're artists and creative-types and the economy is not nice to those!

The biggest challenge here is the time constraint. We can only run this campaign for 60 days, which is about 8 and a half weeks. That means we need to raise, on average, $1200/week. That's a lot of money! But with your help, we can make this thing a reality.

What if I'm also broke and can't donate?

Some people just can't afford to contribute financially, and that's totally okay!

There's other ways you can help us make this happen! This sort of campaign really only pays off if lots of people hear about it, so you can help us as easily as sharing this campaign on your social media feeds! If you'd really like to give us twenty bucks but can't afford to, maybe you've got a friend or two who can!

You can also support us by listening to & sharing episodes of our shows throughout the months of June & July to help raise awareness of our Network and of this campaign!

And, you can tune in every week for a Live Stream where various members of our team will be hanging out and doing fun stuff to try and generate extra donations for the campaign!

Every share and every dollar help get us one step closer to making our dream a reality!

Thanks so much for reading this!

Cheers,

Tom Zalatnai
Executive Producer & Soon-to-be-Dad

And, you can tune in every week for a Live Stream where various members of our team will be hanging out and doing fun stuff to try and generate extra donations for the campaign!

Thanks so much for reading this!
Cheers,
Tom ZalatnaiExecutive Producer & Soon-to-be-Dad

story:
Quick Overview

Hello! My name is Emily Walker. I graduated in December of 2019 with my Bachelor of Science in multiplatform journalism from Florida Institute of Technology. After two months spent working as a reporter at a local newspaper, I was furloughed indefinitely due to COVID-19.

I have been a storyteller my whole life, and it is my dream to pursue this passion professionally. Additionally, it’s important to me to use my passion to help others. This is why I am launching The Spooky Sapphic Storyteller podcast. 

This podcast will mix personal narrative with audio drama. I will voice the host, a 22-year-old journalist/amateur paranormal investigator, and will dive into topics exploring common experiences, challenges, and victories of LGBTQ people. My personal experiences will be woven into this podcast. Along the way, our main character will have some spooky guests on the podcast—specifically LGBTQ ghosts haunting her cabin.  Season one will be approximately 17 episodes.

What I Need & What You Get

I am working to create this podcast with what I already have—a basic microphone, editing software, and my own experiences, writing capabilities, and voice. However, I will need voice actors for certain episodes. The funds I raise will first and foremost go toward paying them for their work. Whatever funds I have remaining will go toward purchasing better recording equipment.

By donating, you’ll not only be helping me produce this podcast, but you’ll also receive perks. For $10, you’ll receive a handwritten thank-you card. For $50, you’ll be given access to a Zoom Q&A/general discussion and hangout for all contributors of $50+, as well as a hand-written thank-you card. For $100, you’ll get the previous perks, as well as hand-drawn/painted character art and a thank-you at the end of every episode.

The Impact

As I said at the beginning, I want to help others through this project. As I was beginning to understand my sexuality and accept myself, hearing the voices of other LGBTQ people was vital. I went from feeling completely alone to having a sense of being seen and understood. My goal is to provide that to others while also having some fun.

Other Ways to Help

Even if you can’t contribute funds, you can still help make this project successful! The most important thing you can do is to share this project with others. A simple post on social media does more than you can imagine.

No matter if you're able to contribute funds or are up for giving this project a shout-out online, I appreciate you. Thank you for believing in me and this project.
story_txt:
Quick Overview
Hello! My name is Emily Walker. I graduated in December of 2019 with my Bachelor of Science in multiplatform journalism from Florida Institute of Technology. After two months spent working as a reporter at a local newspaper, I was furloughed indefinitely due to COVID-19.
I have been a storyteller my whole life, and it is my dream to pursue this passion professionally. Additionally, it’s important to me to use my passion to help others. This is why I am launching The Spooky Sapphic Storyteller podcast. 
This podcast will mix personal narrative with audio drama. I will voice the host, a 22-year-old journalist/amateur paranormal investigator, and will dive into topics exploring common experiences, challenges, and victories of LGBTQ people. My personal experiences will be woven into this podcast. Along the way, our main character will have some spooky guests on the podcast—specifically LGBTQ ghosts haunting her cabin.  Season one will be approximately 17 episodes.

What I Need & What You Get
I am working to create this podcast with what I already have—a basic microphone, editing software, and my own experiences, writing capabilities, and voice. However, I will need voice actors for certain episodes. The funds I raise will first and foremost go toward paying them for their work. Whatever funds I have remaining will go toward purchasing better recording equipment.
By donating, you’ll not only be helping me produce this podcast, but you’ll also receive perks. For $10, you’ll receive a handwritten thank-you card. For $50, you’ll be given access to a Zoom Q&A/general discussion and hangout for all contributors of $50+, as well as a hand-written thank-you card. For $100, you’ll get the previous perks, as well as hand-drawn/painted character art and a thank-you at the end of every episode.

The Impact
As I said at the beginning, I want to help others through this project. As I was beginning to understand my sexuality and accept myself, hearing the voices of other LGBTQ people was vital. I went from feeling completely alone to having a sense of being seen and understood. My goal is to provide that to others while also having some fun.

Other Ways to Help
Even if you can’t contribute funds, you can still help make this project successful! The most important thing you can do is to share this project with others. A simple post on social media does more than you can imagine.
No matter if you're able to contribute funds or are up for giving this project a shout-out online, I appreciate you. Thank you for believing in me and this project.

story:
Our Mission

Our founder, Tom Haig has worked in broadcasting all over the world. Many of his videos have won awards and have brought light to experiences of individuals with disabilities across the world. The goal of Cinema Dakar is to bring the experience of broadcasting to a school of students with disabilities in Dakar, Senegal in Africa. 

What We Need & What You Get

Funding will be going to provide equipment and support for the students while they are learning about what broadcasting can open up to. After the trip is complete, the school will be given the equipment to continue giving students a voice.

The Impact

Your support will give the students a voice to share their experiences. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Visit our facebook or website at rehabforum.org to see our progress as we continue in our journey to Dakar.

story:
Behold: the sound of thunder!

Hello, my friends - I’m Miles Stokes! I’ve been talking about X-Men with Jay Edidin on Jay & Miles X-Plain the X-Men for a few years - and now, I’m ridiculously excited to expound at length about my other great comic book love, Walter Simonson’s 1983-1987 run of The Mighty Thor! Joining me as co-host will be Elisabeth Allie, former marketing manager of Things From Another World and longtime comics fan, and producing will be Kyle Yount, host of Kaijucast and producer of Jay & Miles X-Plain the X-Men.

If this campaign is successful, we’ll be able to create a 12-episode podcast covering the entirety of Simonson’s run: Noble alien horse-dudes! Star-sized fire giants trying to burn down the universe! Villains redeemed through valiant and legitimately tear-jerking sacrifice! And yes, that one time Thor was a cape-wearing frog for a surprisingly long time! 

It won’t just be a list of plot points, of course: Elisabeth and I will be pondering each cluster of issues’ Most Metal Moment, Most Exciting Hat, Worthiest Inanimate Object - all the important stuff. This is my favorite run of comics ever, and I’m excited as Hel for Elisabeth and I to share it with you!

Transforming gold to glory!

Were the Nine Realms truly just, we could merely speak our Asgardian ideas into the World Tree itself to share from Vanaheim to Nidavellir - but here on Midgard, glory ain’t free. If you can help us fund this campaign, we’ll be able to:

  • Pay for high-quality production to sound more like Viking war-bards and less like a couple of random mead-lovers!
  • Host the podcast online for at least a year! 
  • Commission some sweet cover art and maybe even some custom intro music!

If you can contribute any amount, we shall remember you e’er onward in legend and song. But if you can contribute a little more, we’d love to show our gratitude:

  • $5 donors: exclusive access to a special "zero issue" preview episode featuring the non-Simonson fill-in issues of the era, #356 and #370!
  • $10 donors: a personalized Asgardian thank you, emailed as an audio file!

Trust these heroes, honest and bold!

With Miles’s years of experience on a successful X-Men podcast, Elisabeth and Miles’s long careers in the comics industry, and Kyle’s truly ridiculous quantity of amazingly edited podcast episodes across multiple shows, you can count on us to actually deliver a polished and professional set of episodes instead of just mumbling and coughing into a headset for 12 hours.

And: Miles and Elisabeth aren’t just good at talking about comics - they’re good at talking about comics together! We’ve co-hosted a number of podcast episodes together over the last couple of years.

If thine coffers be empty:

Even a small contribution will help us get closer to bringing Asgard to Earth - but if you’re not able to (or even if you are), please share this campaign and let other folks know!

story:
What Is Arcane?

Arcane is a multi-cast supernatural audio drama following a nameless protagonist as he encounters all kinds of supernatural oddities: people trying to steal power/knowledge, spells gone wrong, and people with strange abilities.

Interested? You can listen to the first 7 episodes, Here.

Find out more about the show and what we do, Here.

 

What Are People Saying?

Potatoe Lady Podcast Reviews called it, "short, sweet and intriguing." While Atticus's Attic said, "Arcane is a unique take on the brooding, supernatural serial."

 

Why Are You Asking For Money?

Arcane has thus far been completely self-funded by me, Jacob Quinn. But with my day job hours cut due to Covid and monetization not yet enough to be self-sufficient, I'm unable to fairly compensate my creative team and talented actors for the next 3 episodes. Your help would change that.

 

Only 3 Episodes? Is That The End?

There will be more Arcane after episodes 7, 8, and 9. But by the time those three episodes are live. (Novemberish, with one episode coming out every two months.) I'll be in a better position financially to continue funding future episodes of Arcane.

 

Why Not Wait Until Then?

I want to ensure Arcane continues for those who want to hear it. By asking for help now, I can keep the episodes coming without interruption!

 

What's In It For Me?

In audio drama, they're many parts to creating a compelling whole: The skilled actors who bring the characters to life. The sound and music immersing and informing the show's world and the audio engineering that elevates the voices drawing you into the stories. In other words, you're helping us put together the best possible show that we can.

 

I Love Arcane, But I'm Broke.

Covid has put a strain on so many of us and our families whether it be financially, emotionally, and/or both. My heart goes out to all of you that are struggling. But you can still help even if you can't give a dime. Sharing this on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, email, text, etc. is also an immense help. The more people see this the better chance we have of meeting our goal.

 

Stretch Goals

 

$1,500- Companion Podcast

Wow! We can now purchase better marketing spots to help find people find our show. 

Unlock this level for the "Arcane: Director's Commentary" companion podcast on the first 7 episodes.

 

$2,000- The Process

This handles all the marketing and production costs for the rest of the year.

At this level, I'll release an in-depth video of my step-by-step process of how Arcane is made from the 1st draft of a script all the way to the implementation of the sound design and music.

 

$2,500- Bonus Episode

All expenses are now covered for the foreseeable future. 

If we make it to this level, we'll release a backer's only bonus episode.

story:
Introduction

I started writing The Van in various formats-- novel, script, poem, short story-- four years ago when I was studying film and television. And although it has changed forms many times, I have changed majors, and the world has changed much in that time, it has always been meant to be a story about emotions and what we do with them and how they affect our relationships. Cola (our protagonist) has always been a character so overwhelmed with her own and others' emotions that she spends a lot of time wondering how to escape, if she can or should, and whether or not this makes her a good person. 

In the time between when I started to write The Van and when it was produced, I struggled with a severe eating disorder and depression that caused me to take time off of school and seek treatment. During that time, I ended up trying to answer a lot of Cola's questions myself and realized what I was asking was can one survive and even thrive when their emotions seem to difficult to handle? It was a much tougher question to wrestle with than I initially understood. Now I've been in recovery for years and Cola's journey has expanded to include my experience and my newer questions.

This story is extremely personal and important to me. I've been lucky enough to have a team and a cast work with me for virtually no money up until this point, but because I owe them the debt of helping me tell this story, I want to make sure they are fairly compensated for the work they've done and for future work. That's what this campaign is for.

-Em

What We Need & What You Get

Our goal is to raise $2,200. This money will go to paying our cast and crew and for some small resources like printing and Patreon reward costs.

What do you get?

1. Our show. We create our show for free because we like to offer free meaningful media to you. We've been overwhelmed with the beautiful responses we get from listeners who find The Van important. We hope it will be important to you too.

2. In a more exciting sense, prizes. We'll be offering perks like thank you notes from characters, poems from Cola, exclusive stickers, and road trip packages!

The Impact

As a film student, I was often encouraged to do projects for free, work for experience and connections, and expect others to do the same. When I first started creating The Van, I was in that mindset, unfortunately. But now I have spent precious time with talented and kind and courageous artists who have taught me the importance of offering compensation to people that work on projects.

In the arts, it is already hard enough for marginalized people to make their way, even in communities that can self-laud for their commitment to diversity and growth and easy access like the podcasting community. It takes cold, hard resources, like money and equipment for people to even get a leg up. I'd like to keep growing the diversity of our cast and crew by hiring more artists of color and even more queer artists and in order to do that, it is important that we pay them for their time and effort. Your money goes towards expanding the industry and offering opportunities for people to create while being compensated fairly.

Risks & Challenges

The biggest challenge lately for me and my team has been time. Many of us are students. I particularly am I social work student heading into my senior year where I have to begin applying to grad school, building up my resume, and doing a (regrettably free) internship that requires a lot of time and emotional energy. I (or my fantastic editor Cristian) can often be delayed by exams, jobs, or just extreme exhaustion.

However, after a season of learning, we are getting better at preparation and doing things ahead of time before a problem can arise. I am also getting better at asking for help and collaboration from the fantastic podcasting community. With this campaign, the goal is to not allow anything to waylay the work that needs to be done, even if it is a struggle. We're committed to carrying out this campaign in a timely and dedicated fashion.

Other Ways You Can Help

1. Share our campaign! Everywhere! Twitter is good. We're hot on twitter. But also facebook is good because parents and grandparents and family friends that vaguely know people involved in our project like to donate!

2. Listen to our show! You'll like it. Promise.

And, as always, 

vroom vroom

story:
The Tolkien Road  is a podcast focused on an in-depth exploration of the works and philosophy of JRR Tolkien. Started in 2015, co-hosts John & Greta Carswell have produced over 140 episodes exploring The Lord of the Rings, The Silmarillion, and other aspects of Tolkien-dom. And now we are turning our attention to the story that started it all: The Hobbit.

This 8 episode podcast series will include in-depth, chapter-by-chapter discussions of the first six chapters of The Hobbit, and conclude with a discussion of Peter Jackson's film The Hobbit - An Unexpected Journey. We'll also include a special look at the character Gollum, and consider his overall significance in the stories of Middle-earth.

Here's the plan by episode:

  1. Chapter 1 - An Unexpected Party
  2. Chapter 2 - Roast Mutton
  3. Chapter 3 - A Short Rest
  4. Chapter 4 - Over Hill and Under Hill
  5. Chapter 5 - Riddles in the Dark
  6. Chapter 6 - Out of the Frying-Pan into the Fire
  7. Concerning Gollum
  8. Peter Jackson's The Hobbit - An Unexpected Journey
  9. BONUS EPISODE: more info below

While it's a labor of love, Tolkien's works deserve the very best of what we have to offer. Therefore, we need your help to fund the production of these episodes, and also to pave the way for future seasons!

WHAT WE NEED & WHAT YOU GET

We are aiming to raise $500 for this season. That will help us cover the cost of production (we'll be honest: it takes a lot of time and work to produce one of these episodes!).

You can contribute at the following levels (all contributors will be entered in a special grand-prize drawing):

  • $1+: Get entered into our grand prize drawing! We appreciate your appreciation of the hard work we put into The Tolkien Road!!!
  • $5+: Become a Patron of this season! You'll get a shout-out in the end credits of each episode this season, AND you'll get a BONUS episode only available to $5+ patrons.
  • $25+: All the previous stuff PLUS get a Signed, Limited Edition First Printing copy of Tolkien's Overture as well as a signed copy of Tolkien's Requiem.
  • $100+: Executive Producer! You'll be listed as one of our Executive Producers at the beginning of each episode this season, and you have an invitation to join us via Skype for our discussion of Peter Jackson's The Hobbit: An Unexpected Journey.

THE DIFFERENCE YOU CAN MAKE

While we've produced over 140 hours of discussion about Tolkien's works over the last several years, when you add in all of the time preparing and producing the episodes, it actually adds up to quite a bit more. We want to make this show as great as possible, and every dollar you send our way is more wind in our sails!

And if we can double our goal (ie hit $1000), we will produce 2 extra episodes along with this batch.

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

Even if you can't contribute, if you can share this campaign with others who might be interested, we'd greatly appreciate it!

story:
About Annex

Annex is an audio serial (podcast) where Knots Landing meets Chinatown in the Pacific Northwest of the early twentieth century.

  • Five seasons or connected arcs (consisting of 13 episodes per arc) tell the story of Halfway-There, one of the neighborhoods just outside the port city of Harborview.
  • Taking place between 1913 and 1929, Annex uses techniques of audio drama to depict the struggles and scandals along this stretch of Delaney Avenue, which proves central in a grand conspiracy extending the reach of Harborview’s criminal underworld into the backyards, gardens, alleys, basements, parlors, kitchens, and bedrooms of the growing community of Halfway-There.
  • The world of Annex was inspired by extensive historical research on Portland neighborhoods and PNW life in the early 20th century.  

 

About the Creator: Drew Beard

Annex co-creator and story editor Drew Beard was born and raised in Clark County, Washington. After earning a PhD from the University of Oregon in Eugene, Drew moved to Portland, Oregon, where he teaches film and television courses at Portland State University, including a class on “The TV Serial.”

 

What We Need & What You Get

Annex is produced by Drew Beard, Christi Dodge, and a team of volunteers (including a number of Portland State University film majors). Drew has finished writing season 1 of Annex and has mapped out story arcs for the remaining four seasons. Casting is currently underway. We need your help gearing up for production and managing the costs of hosting the podcast:

  • Our $4,800 flexible goal will help us purchase microphones and get access to a recording studio. Because this is an audio drama with many characters, our goal is to have all of our actors in the recording studio at once. The funds will also help us cover the practical costs of hard drives, editing software, and hosting.
  • If we don't reach our entire goal, we'll purchase (or rent) the best equipment we can afford to bring you, the listener, great sounding audio.
  • If we exceed our goal, part of the funds will go toward paying our actors and reimbursing some of our many volunteers. Exceeding our goal also gives us access to better audio equipment and effects. 
  • You can make your own mark on the city of Harborview with our perks. At $25+, you can name a street, business, or character in the story. Donors who contribute $150+ can receive a tote bag and a personal thank you note from Drew, the creator. At the $500+ level, you can have a walk-on role.  

 

The Impact

Discover the PNW of years past, when city borders encroached on the wilderness. Explore Portland before it was Portlandia and life in the wild of the PNW before it was #thatpnwlife. Annex is an exciting story of a bygone era, complete with drama, intrigue, and memorable characters. If you have $5 to spare, you can help us bring our story to life.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute, you can still help by sharing the podcast with your friends, colleagues, and family on social media. Please help us spread the word!

story:
About The Creators

Hosts Rob & Heff have a combined 30+ years in the craft beer industry.  When they became friends through their business dealings as a retailer and a salesman, they found out that they had a lot of other things in common.  They were both passionate about music, tacos, sports, travel, tacos, charity, and a burning hatred for the NY Yankees.

When Rob's previous show came to a close, he thought his videocasting career was over.  However, when they attended opening day at the Nationals, people kept coming up to him and asking when he would have another show.  Heff knew it was time to help his friend get back in the game, and together they conceived of a beer show that gets outside the bottle.  Now they are on  a mission to get the craft beer community to expand its orbit.  

In a stroke of real serendipity, Tony, the show's director, had just moved on from his long time job working as a video artist and marketing guy for a local brewery.  It seemed too good to be true, that two completely unpolished slobs would end up with an actual professional behind the camera and editing board, but here they are.

The $ goal provides the resources for 2 months of shooting and 8+ web-length videos (4 TV-length half hours), that they can then take to  advertisers and raise funds to complete Season 1.

Tony Gotta Eat

If you've read a DuClaw Brewing Company bottle label or watched one of
their videos produced between 2007 and 2017, you're familiar with the work
of the man behind the camera.

Tony Marion is a script-to-screen filmmaker and senior-level copywriter
with more than 25 years of experience. He has written, produced, directed,
shot, and edited (including VFX, motion graphics, and audio editing) over
300 projects, and lent his skills in various support capacities to more
than 50 others. His work has been seen on MTV and the FOX Network, in
projects created by Activision and NASA, and on numerous YouTube Channels
and corporate sites around the web.

Now he can add the prestigious title of Beercentrics director to that resume, but here's the thing: Tony is a full-time freelancer now, and Rob & Heff want him all to themselves for the next 8 episodes.  Rob & Heff have day jobs, and the show itself is not for profit, but for Tony to be able to put full focus on Beercentrics, we'll need your help.

What You Get

Aside from the joy of seeing two weirdo beer nerds continue to annoy local business proprietors, on a more frequent basis, they are assembling an arsenal of swag to compensate you for your contributions.  Some highlights:

$10 gets you a Beercentrics branded glass

$30 gets you a Beercentrics branded t-shirt

$50 gets you a Beercentrics branded disc golf disc + t-shirt (or set of two glasses)

Why Are They Doing This?

Craft beer is significantly changing the financial landscape of towns and neighborhoods across the country.  The existence of a brewery can completely reshape the value and attraction to both prospective residents and fellow business owners, while bolstering their existing peers and natives.  We hope to highlight what else makes these places unique, and encourage beer people to check out the diverse offerings that might be right next door.

Rob & Heff have long been cheerleaders for the craft beer community, and are looking to expand their megaphone to keep the industry healthy for decades to come.

Other Ways You Can Help

It's not in everybody's budget to make contributions to projects like this, and that is totally understood.  If you can't financially support, please consider sharing our project with your people on social media, or however you keep in touch.  Thanks and cheers!

story:
Wer?

Mein Name ist Lars Naber, ich produziere seit 2015 den Podcast "Auf Distanz". Darin geht es um Astronomie und Raumfahrt und dabei werden viele Themen besprochen: Neue Techniken und Beobachtungen im All, aber auch Satelliten- und Raumfahrtmissionen.

Was?

Natürlich geht es auch um Missionen der astronautischen Raumfahrt. Eine solche ist die "Horizons"-Mission. Im Rahmen dieser Mission wird der ESA-Astronaut Alexander Gerst wieder ins All starten. Am 6. Juni 2018 geht es los, die Rückkehr ist für Dezember 2018 vorgesehen.

Ich werde für "Auf Distanz" diese Mission intensiv verfolgen und habe auch die Möglichkeit, den Start von Alexander Gerst in Baikonur zu verfolgen. Für rund acht Tage werde ich in Kasachstan sein, die Hauptstadt Astana besuchen, die Raumfahrtanlagen in Baikonur besichtigen und am Schluss hoffentlich Alexander Gerst bei seinem Start ins All hinterher blicken.

Diese Reise wird mir zur Hälfte möglich gemacht durch die bevuta IT in Köln, für den Rest bitte ich Dich um Unterstützung.

Wofür?

Mit Deinem Beitrag unterstützt Du ein offenes Podcast-Projekt, das im Internet frei und schrankenlos für alle erreichbar ist.

Für die Reise gibt es eine eigene Webseite. Dort nehme ich Dich virtuell mit auf die Reise. Es wird tägliche Berichte und Fotos geben. Meinem Reisepartner Pablo Beyen und ich werden jeden Tag eine Podcast-Episode veröffentlichen, in der wir über unsere Erlebnisse erzählen werden. Wenn es die Internet-Verbindung zulässt, soll es auch Videos geben.

Dieses ist eine offene Kampagne. Jeder Euro hilft, die Reise und die Berichte noch runder und besser zu machen. Neben den Reisekosten investiere ich in technische Ausstattung, um die Reise richtig gut dokumentieren zu können.

Sollte Geld übrig bleiben, fließt das in künftige Episoden für den Podcast.

Danke!

Wenn Du das Projekt unterstützen möchtest: Vielen Dank! Ich habe drei Belohnungsstufen eingerichtet.

Unterstützen ohne Belohnung
Wenn Du das Projekt einfach nur unterstützen möchtest, aber keine Gegenleistung erwartest, kannst Du diese Stufe nutzen.

Unterstützen mit Andenken
Ab 10 Euro Beitrag in dieser Stufe sende ich Dir zur Erinnerung an Deine Unterstützung Aufkleber und eine Dankeschön-Karte zu.

Unterstützen und Reisebericht besuchen
Wenn Du 30 Euro oder mehr spendest, freue ich mich, Dich im nächsten Jahr bei einer zusammenfassenden Dokumentation der Reise in Köln begrüßen zu dürfen. Wie genau die ablaufen wird, ist noch in intensiver Planung, aber ein paar Dinge sind schon klar: Ich werde Euch an diesem Abend nochmal virtuell mit auf die Reise nach Kasachstan nehmen und von der Reise und dem Drumherum ausführlich berichten.

Damit das nun nicht fade wird wie so mancher Dia-Abend in der Verwandtschaft, habe ich mir Verstärkung dazu geholt: Mit dabei sein werden Martin Rützler vom Podcast "Radio Mono" sowie Reinhard Remfort und Nicolas Wöhrl vom Podcast „Methodisch Inkorrekt“.

Wir werden für den Abend einiges auf die Beine stellen. Lass' Dich überraschen!

Die Aufkleber und die Dankeschön-Karte sind natürlich auch hier mit dabei.

Kann etwas schiefgehen?

Es kann natürlich Faktoren geben, die das Erlebnis mindern. Wenn der Raketenstart verschoben wird, werde ich ihn vermutlich nicht erleben können. Aber die anderen Sehenswürdigkeiten und Erlebnisse bleiben natürlich und die Begleitung der "Horizons"-Mission im Podcast wird davon auch nicht berührt werden.

Fragen?

Wenn Du Fragen über das Projekt hast, nimm' bitte einfach Kontakt mit mir auf. Beim Profil gibt es die „Stelle eine Frage“-Funktion, ich antworte Dir dann schnellstmöglich.

Teilen...

Wenn Du meinst, dieses Projekt könnte für jemanden interessant sein, bitte erzähle es weiter. Danke!
